Matrix multiplication involves multiplying corresponding elements of two matrices and summing the products to form the resulting matrix. The shape of the resulting matrix will be the same as the two matrices being multiplied (rows of the first matrix by columns of the second matrix). For example, if A is a 3x2 matrix (3 rows, 2 columns) and B is a 2x3 matrix (2 rows, 3 columns), then the resulting matrix C will be 3x3 (3 rows, 3 columns). The elements of C can be calculated using the formula c(i,j) = a(i,1) * b(1,j) + a(i,2) * b(2,j), where a(i,j) and b(k,l) represent the elements of matrices A and B, respectively, with i and k representing rows, and j and l representing columns. 8. In computer science and programming, a subclass is a class that inherits some or all of the properties and methods of a parent or superclass. The child class is the subclass, while the parent class is the superclass. Subclasses can extend or override the methods and properties of their parent classes. However, subclasses cannot add new properties without explicit inheritance. 9. In the concept of inheritance, the subclass is a child class that inherits from the parent class known as a superclass. The subclass can also be referred to as the derived class, as it derives some or all properties and methods from the base or parent class. It essentially serves as a blueprint for the subclass, and the subclass can inherited properties from the parent class and add new properties. 10.
